title: The Drugs Trial looks at 'Elephant Man' trial left 6 with failing organs and amputated limbs | Metro News
text:
Georgia Diebelius for Metro.co.uk Wednesday 22 Feb 2017 9:52 am Doctors worked to save the men (Picture: BBC) 
More than 11 years ago, six young men were left writhing in agony with their organs failing after agreeing to take part in a routine drugs trial in London. 
The group were part of a team of eight who were each offered £2,000 to help potentially revolutionise cancer treatment. Facebook ‘is down’ for many users as News Feed stops working – and people aren’t happy 
Aged between 19 and 34, the men believed that their worst symptoms would be a headache or even a batch of nausea. 
However, soon after receiving the drug, six were left vomiting and screaming in agony – with several having to have body parts amputated. 
Now, a BBC documentary has revisited the dramatic events that left the human guinea pigs fighting for their lives in a private unit at Northwick Park Hospital in north-west London run by Parexel, a US company. To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser that supports HTML5 video Ryan Wilson lost his fingertips as a result (Picture: Channel 4) Raste Khan said everyone around him was in pain, he was unaware that he had been given a placebo (Picture: BBC/Raw TV) 
Throughout the Phase 1 trial, a number of the men suffered from swelling – with their heads inflating like balloons. 
One of the victim’s family said he looked like ‘the Elephant Man’, therefore leaving the TGN1412 drug trial with the nickname ‘the Elephant Man drug trial’. 
The drug, which had been successfully tried out on monkeys, had never been tested on humans. The ‘ketchup problem’ could be solved as scientists unveil ‘magic’ bottle 
The incident quickly transformed into one of Britain’s most infamous medical emergencies. 
Fortunately, doctors were able to save the lives of all of the young men – and a few weeks later, five of the men were able to leave hospital. 
Ryan Wilson, the sixth and youngest participant aged 21, spent the next four months being treated for heart, liver and kidney failure. 
Sections of his feet were amputated and his fingertips also fell off. 
It was later revealed that two of the participants were given a placebo, and did not suffer the effects. Participant David Oakley was in the trial (Picture: BBC/Raw TV) All of the men had their lives saved (Picture: BBC) 
In the documentary, The Drugs Trial, which aired last night, doctors speak about the struggles they faced while attempting to bring the ‘mysterious’ situation under control. 
Investigators also reveal that they were sent in and tasked with finding out what went wrong at the trial on March 13, 2006. 
Participant Raste Khan, who was 23 at the time and had been given a placebo, said: ‘Medical trials were like a get-rich-quick-scheme. It was a no brainer. Evacuation after unexploded 500lb WWII bomb is found at bottom of harbour 
‘It was all manic, everything was happening all at once. They were vomiting, they were screaming in pain, people were fainting, they couldn’t control their bowels… it was like a horror movie.’ 
In the documentary, it was revealed that families were told to say goodbye to their loved ones as they may be about to die. 
Since the disaster, some of the participants have received compensation from Parexel. 
A report published by The Medicines & Healthcare Products Regulatory Agency in April 2006 had 22 recommendations to improve the safety of future Phase 1 trials. More
